TODOr is a sweet #RStats package that’s really handy for package developers.

If you write comments such as TODO, FIXME, IDEA etc as you’re working in an RStudio project, a call to `todor()` lists in a ‘Markers’ pane all the places they occur, and any further comment alongside them.

This makes it really easy to see what needs doing/fixing etc and to go back to those places.

The package also provides an RStudio Addin.

last_post.content: #monotile Reading this https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/quasiblog/aperiodic-tilings/ on plotting monotiles, it talks about substitution rules making smaller and smaller tiles, but it seemed to me there should be a recurrence relation for plotting larger and larger monotiled patches from the H7/H8 rule. And there is, here's my code https://gist.github.com/bazzargh/961b6765042b17c0c25eadcc98b080e6 this also explains why H7/H8 tiles have 7/8 tiles at the base layer (one flipped) and 6/7 in later layers-the flipped tile is a hole!

title: github.com/EthanRosenthal/nn-v...

last_post.content:
New blog post: Do you actually need a vector database?
https://www.ethanrosenthal.com/2023/04/10/nn-vs-ann/

To go along with the blog post, I made a small repo to benchmark using a "vector DB" (aka approximate nearest neighbors) with "brute-force" nearest neighbors https://github.com/EthanRosenthal/nn-vs-ann

The main takeaway is that the brute-force method takes ~50 milliseconds / 1 million embeddings on my computer, so hopefully those numbers can help you to make a decision on whether you need a vector DB!

title: Release 23.1.0 · hynek/structlog

last_post.content:
I'm happy to announce structlog 23.1.0!

The main reason for the release are two bugs around exception logging, but it also brings config-less async logging to standard library integration: just switch `log.info()` into `await log.ainfo()`!

In acceptance of structlog increasingly being used in CLI contexts, the default configuration now respects the FORCE_COLOR and NO_COLOR variables and therefore acts as expected without any configuration.

Enjoy: https://github.com/hynek/structlog/releases/tag/23.1.0

title: github.com/ronilaukkarinen/mas...

last_post.content:
#Mastodon is far better than any microblogging service out there. It has all the features that many don't, for example content warnings, editing posts, high character count, post visibility settings per post etc... It's a dream as platform. However #UI-wise I think it still has long way to go. The current default UI feels old-ish and a bit clunky. Thankfully it can be improved with apps and UIs.

Because Mastodon is #OpenSource, I've been able to make changes to my own instance. I've seen lots of different social media UI's since the times of Jaiku and there are good choices that have been forgotten. The hellsite got most of it right and it's been my inspiration in regards to user interface. As a designer and developer I create the UI improvements for myself that I think Mastodon is missing.

Hence, the #MastodonBirdUI was born.

There have been lots of subtle changes over the weeks in my instance. Let me present some of these. I'm quite proud of what I have achieved as a designer and developer. My instance is now top notch for me. There is always room for improvement, but it's already like 99.9% there.

I just hope Mastodon itself will get even a pinch of these in the core, some day. Most notably the real numbers for OCD and neurodivergent people, free resizing of the compose box (#a11y), one level threads and if one can hope, a bit of white space and minimalism in the design.

Preview: https://mementomori.social

Get Mastodon Bird UI here: https://github.com/ronilaukkarinen/mastodon-bird-ui

Edit: Fixed some typos

#UI #CSS #MastoAdmin #Accesibility #OCD #Perfectionism #Design #UIDesign

@hasanahmsd @caseynewton @jeffjarvis Here's something fun: I have the ChatGPT alpha that can use Python, so I posed the problem to that (using different words to avoid confusion)

> Based on the depth-first search algorithm, there is no solution to this puzzle. It's impossible for the man to take the zelpug, sphang, and cnurdle across the river while obeying all three rules. Therefore, the man cannot solve this puzzle and get all three things across the river.

title: github.com/mlc-ai/web-stable-d...

last_post.content: There are already some crazy things out there, like a version of Stable Diffusion that runs in your web browser. https://github.com/mlc-ai/web-stable-diffusion. I wrote something two years ago about why I think WebGPU makes javascript the most interesting programming language out there for data analysts/ML people. https://benschmidt.org/post/2020-01-15-webGPU/ And there's lots of stuff that's become more conceivable since--for instance, a dataframe based on Apache Arrow that does massively parallel data transformations. Chat-GPT in browser.
